comment.author: 21539212@N08
comment._content:
If you see lots of internment photos and films, as I have, the incarcerees usually look happy. These were their family photos, not conscious documentation of the injustice they were living under.

muI think the daily life they built in the camps, which was filled with a lot of pretty "normal" activities like employment and pastimes, didn't leave much time for sitting around and looking miserable over the hardships and fundamental betrayal dealt them by the U.S. government.

Also, photography by incarcerees was officially banned in the camps though the restriction was eventually relaxed. This undoubtedly caused a lot of negative sights to be hidden from cameras. I've read that Dorothea Lange took a lot of photos that revealed the harsh realities of the internment camps, but I haven't found them online yet -- hopefully they'll be available soon.

comment.author: 50742523@N05
comment._content:
As someone mentioned above, Dorothea Lange as well as others (like Ansel Adams) took photos at some of these camps for government purposes.  Lange was unable to visit Tule Lake.

Cameras and most other personal items were prohibited or were confiscated so nearly all photos in the public domain are those taken by the government.  In addition, these government photos were "posed" and did not reflect the tension within the camps.  The Kodak 4x5 positive film would be a good indication this was a government photo - likely taken with a Speed Graphic.

Still, a nice photo for this collection.
